executive_summary: Pasta and noodles produced by the Dry Pasta Production industry are both staples in the American diet. Versatility and simple cooking instructions keep demand for the industry relatively stable, despite changes in consumer diets and preferences. Even as gluten-free and grain-free diets have become more popular, the industry has maintained demand by offering alternative products. Instead, changes in prices have affected industry revenue over the five years to 2023. During the period, the world price of wheat has surged due to supply chain disruptions. Additionally, while imports have increased, domestic manufacturers have made efforts to increase exports.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: COVID-19 Created Volatility for Pasta Producers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Unlike many other industries, during the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, the Dry Pasta Production industry saw revenue grow, as restaurants closed and more people were forced to cook meal at home. When lockdowns were lifted in 2021, demand from consumers fell, leading to revenue declines. However, as the economy returned to a normal state in 2022, revenue returned to growth. As the pandemic has fully passed, dry pasta revenue is expected to enter into a more stable period.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Wheat Prices and Import Competition Threaten US Pasta Producers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The global price of wheat largely determines Dry Pasta industry revenue because wheat is the largest input to the industry and manufacturers are able to pass price increases on to consumers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Falling Wheat Prices and Heightened Competition Will Challenge Revenue Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As wheat prices have grown, US pasta producers have raised prices to avoid significant profit losses. Imports contribute a major part to the competition, with Italy alone accounting for more than half of the industry imports, whereas an increased production in low-wage countries like Mexico and China threatens the domestic industry further. Since 2018, imports have grown as income levels have increased and people have had higher demand for slightly more expensive pasta from Italy.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A projected decline in the world price of wheat, one of the primary ingredients in pasta, will likely force pasta businesses to decrease their prices.
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite potential shifts in demographic eating habits after COVID-19, pasta's status as a staple food in many diets will help maintain a level of demand.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Industry Consolidation and Reduced Workforce Anticipated
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Lower input costs and high competition will keep profit margins low, likely causing continued consolidation within the industry. Large companies in the industry have historically looked toward acquisitions as a means of growing market share. As the industry consolidates, economies of scale will allow larger companies to increase automation and reduce employment. As a result, profit margins are expected to remain healthy, while labor costs are expected to fall.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Post-Pandemic Consumer Habits May Impact Trade Levels
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The pasta industry may face less competition from imports with the long-term economic consequences of the pandemic causing consumer spending to slow in the coming years. High-quality, higher-priced pasta from Italy is anticipated to decrease slightly in dominance as disposable income levels take time to recover and domestic, lower-priced pasta becomes more appealing to customers.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures dry pasta products after purchasing ingredients from other food manufacturers. The end products are then packaged and distributed to grocery wholesalers, supermarkets and other food outlets.
key_trends: Demand for pasta grew during the pandemic, despite lockdowns.
Demand for dry pasta has been volatile as the economy has slowly moved beyond the pandemic.
Changing consumer diets have created opportunities for innovation.
Gluten-free and grain-free pastas have created new opportunities for pasta producers.
The price of wheat determines the price of dry pasta. Demand for pasta is stable so pasta producers can pass cost increases on to consumers.
Pasta producers must maintain food safety standards. The industry is subject to the regulation of the Food and Drug Administration.
Grain-free pastas have cut into the market share of traditional styles of pasta. White-flour pasta remains the largest source of dry pasta industry revenue.
Food service has grown as a market for dry pasta since the pandemic. During the pandemic, restaurants closed, cutting off a major market for dry pasta sales.
The West remains the most significant region for pasta production. The regions population centers and access to grain attracts pasta

market_segmentation.segment_description: Retail stores include supermarkets, grocery stores, gas stations and convenience stores. Mass merchandisers, like Target and Walmart, have expanded their grocery product selection, helping boost this market segment's performance. In economic downturns, lower disposable incomes cause consumers to purchase more groceries at supermarkets rather than dine out at restaurants. As disposable income levels improve, consumers tend to buy products with perceivably better quality and higher prices, improving revenue for retailers.

Grocery wholesalers purchase dry pasta from manufacturers and distribute it in bulk to supermarkets, mass merchandisers, convenience stores and food service customers. Wholesalers represent the most important link in the supply chain since most retailers and food service providers rely on wholesalers for primary inputs. Wholesalers' share of revenue has dropped through the end of 2023 since supermarket chains and big-box retailers have expansively turned to purchase goods directly from manufacturers. The ability to purchase directly from a manufacturer also gives retailers more negotiation power.

Restaurants and other food service establishments provide a significant market for pasta producers. Pasta is a staple food in American and Italian cuisine so many restaurants need some form of pasta. High-end Italian restaurants are more likely to make pasta in-house, so demand is often strongest from restaurants that don't specialize in pasta dishes. Demand from restaurants plummeted during the pandemic, but surged back in 2021 and 2022 when restaurants were allowed to fully reopen.

tier_1_suppliers: Corn, Wheat & Soybean Wholesaling in the US
Industrial Machinery & Equipment Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Wheat, Barley & Sorghum Farming in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: WHITE-FLOUR PASTA STILL DOMINATES DESPITE RISING DEMAND FOR HEALTHIER OPTIONS
demand_determinants.determinant_description: White-flour pasta represents the largest product segment for pasta producers because white-flour pasta is the most traditional pasta would be considered the default. Despite a decreasing market share over the last five years, it remains as the largest product segment in the industry. Its high carbohydrate and sugar content has drawn consumers towards whole-grain or gluten-free alternatives.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: ASIAN NOODLES STRUGGLED DURING THE PANDEMIC
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Asian noodles and egg noodles have remained stable as household staples, but demand was slightly dented in 2020 amid anti-Chinese attitudes prompted by Covid-19. Despite being manufactured locally, many American consumers feared Asian products due to the virus's origin from China. As the pandemic has passed, demand for ramen and other Asian-style noodles has recovered.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: SURGE IN GLUTEN-FREE DIETS INCREASES REVENUE FOR GLUTEN-FREE PASTAS
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Gluten-free pasta has grown in popularity due to greater awareness of gluten intolerance diseases and health concerns over high gluten diets. Pasta producers are capitalizing on the trend by incorporating gluten-free flours, legumes, and other non-wheat ingredients in their product lines These products are usually sold at a premium, creating a revenue boost for pasta producers.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: WHOLE-WHEAT AND ORGANIC PASTAS HIGHLIGHT A SHIFT TOWARDS HEALTH-CONSCIOUS CHOICES
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for whole-wheat and organic pastas has been driven by increasing consumer awareness towards conditions like obesity and diabetes.

international_trade_points.trade_description: - Proximity to end markets allow manufacturers to take advantage of lower transport and distribution costs. - US producers have access to an abundant supply of key inputs needed to manufacture dry pasta, including flour and wheat. - However, demand for Italian pasta and Asian ramen keep demand for imports high because products from these countries will always be seen as more authentic.

international_trade_points.trade_title: WHILE IMPORTS REMAIN REGIONAL, NEW AVENUES WILL WIDEN OVER THE COMING YEARS
international_trade_points.trade_description: - The proximity and favorable trade environment under the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement encourage high import penetration from Canada and Mexico. - Imports from Asia, specifically China, have remained relatively high because of the low production costs in these countries. - Following trade disruptions due to the COVID-19 pandemic, imports surged in 2022.

international_trade_points.trade_title: THE LOW-VALUE NATURE OF PASTA LIMITS EXPORTS
international_trade_points.trade_description: - The low value of dry pasta makes it relatively expensive to transport. - The growing variety of pastas, including gluten- and grain-free options, has expanded the appeal of US-produced snacks abroad. - Since most packaged foods are perishable, many of the leading pasta producers have established production facilities abroad to satisfy international demand for their products.

international_trade_points.trade_title: THE STRENGTHENING US DOLLAR LIMITS OPPORTUNITIES ABROAD
international_trade_points.trade_description: The strength of the US dollar limits export opportunities, as the strong domestic currency makes goods being exported more expensive relative to other currencies. Most products for export are routed to neighboring countries, with Canada and Mexico the two largest trading partners for dry good exports.

business_locations.location_description: The Mid-Atlantic region is home to some of the biggest and most affluent cities in the United States, including Philadelphia, New York City and Washington, DC. The Mid-Atlantic is also a major hub for downstream food service providers, including hotels and restaurants. The region houses extensive rail infrastructure networks that facilitate trade.

Florida which resides in the Southeast has a large population, providing a large consumer base for pasta producers. The region provides access to key raw materials, like sugar, and relatively inexpensive, abundant labor.

California, which resides in the West, houses the most pasta producers. The large and affluent consumer base, well-established infrastructure and easy access to big population centers, such as San Francisco, Los Angeles and Seattle, make this region an ideal location for manufacturers. The West holds an ever-expanding population and has a significant manufacturing footprint. Producers here minimize downstream distribution Costs by locating near end consumers

regulations_points.regulation_description: The FDA regulates the Dry Pasta Production industry by enforcing rules established by the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) and the Fair Packaging and Labeling Act. The Nutrition Labeling and Education Act, which amended the FD&C Act, requires most food products to bear labeling regarding nutrition, nutrition claims and certain health messages. Failure to abide by FDA rules can seriously impair a producer's credibility, result in expensive product recalls and lead to civil liability or criminal penalties.

OSHA is a federal agency responsible for enforcing safety and health legislation in the United States. Under the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, Congress created OSHA to set and regulate standards for safe and healthy working conditions for men and women. Major pasta producers must adhere to OSHA regulation carefully because of their high level of scrutiny given their number of facilities and high volume of workers.

The EPA and state governments enforce environmental regulations on food processing industries. Various federal environmental regulations and statutes, like the Clean Water Act (CWA), Clean Air Act, Pollution Prevention Act (PPA) and Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, have changed how processing facilities handle products and dispose of waste. When a food facility discharges any waste into the environment, it must have a National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit as mandated in the CWA.

barriers_points.barrier_description: While most pasta producers rely on manual labor to operate machinery, larger producers have adequate funding to invest in labor-saving machinery.

basis_points.basis_description: Grain-free pastas have threatened traditional pasta producers. Health conscious consumers have increasingly looked toward non-traditional pastas as a healthier option.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Large Pasta Producers Manage Multiple Brands
concentration_points.concentration_description: Some of the largest companies in the Dry Pasta Production industry have established their market share by acquiring small brands and diversifying. Large companies like Barilla and Ebro Foods operate multiple pasta brands that are all meant to cater to different consumer tastes and preferences. The operation of multiple brands under a single parent makes the industry appear less concentrated than it is.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: INPUT VOLATILITY EQUATES TO UNCERTAIN PURCHASE COSTS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: COVID-19 caused the prices of multiple key inputs to skyrocket because of strong global demand and continued supply chain challenges. Prices of key production inputs, including wheat, sugar yeast and starch, which are the primary drivers of purchase costs, have fluctuated through the end of 2023.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Producers are expanding their purchases of gluten- and grain-free ingredients
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Producers are expanding their purchases of gluten- and grain-free ingredients, such as nut and seed flour to cater to increasingly health-conscious consumers, which are typically high in cost.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Packaging materials constitute a substantial portion of purchases
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Packaging materials constitute a substantial portion of purchases since producers use plastic, cardboard, paper and other products to package finished goods. These inputs also endure price fluctuations.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Global Wheat Prices Determine Revenue Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Wheat is the largest input for pasta production, so as wheat prices fluctuate, the cost of manufacturing dry pasta changes as well. Demand for pasta is driven by consumer habits, and overall, demand for dry pasta is resistant to small changes in prices. As a result, pasta producers are typically able to pass price increases on to consumers. Since 2018, wheat prices have been volatile as severe weather patterns and the pandemic have disrupted wheat production.

Unlike many other products, dry pasta revenue grew during the pandemic because lockdowns and restaurant closures led to more people cooking at home. As a result, in 2021 when lockdowns were lifted and restaurants reopened, demand for dry pasta plummeted. Since then, revenue has slightly stabilized, though shifts in the price of wheat continue to drive volatility.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: WHITE-FLOUR PASTA STILL DOMINATES DESPITE RISING DEMAND FOR HEALTHIER OPTIONS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: White-flour pasta represents the largest product segment for pasta producers because white-flour pasta is the most traditional pasta would be considered the default. Despite a decreasing market share over the last five years, it remains as the largest product segment in the industry. Its high carbohydrate and sugar content has drawn consumers towards whole-grain or gluten-free alternatives.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: ASIAN NOODLES STRUGGLED DURING THE PANDEMIC
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Asian noodles and egg noodles have remained stable as household staples, but demand was slightly dented in 2020 amid anti-Chinese attitudes prompted by Covid-19. Despite being manufactured locally, many American consumers feared Asian products due to the virus's origin from China.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Surge in Gluten-Free Diets Increases Revenue for Gluten-Free Pastas
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Gluten-free pasta has grown in popularity due to greater awareness of gluten intolerance diseases and health concerns over high gluten diets. Pasta producers are capitalizing on the trend by incorporating gluten-free flours, legumes, and other non-wheat ingredients in their product lines. These products are usually sold at a premium, creating a revenue boost for pasta producers.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Whole-Wheat and Organic Pastas Highlight a Shift Towards Health-Conscious Choices
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Demand for whole-wheat and organic pastas has been driven by increasing consumer awareness towards conditions like obesity and diabetes.

FAQs.question: How have imports from low-wage countries like China and Mexico impacted your operations?
FAQs.answer: China and Mexico are key contributors to domestic demand. Their continuous presence provides security to domestic companies.

FAQs.question: How does the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulate the food processing industry?
FAQs.answer: The EPA and state governments enforce environmental regulations on food processing industries. Various federal environmental regulations and statutes, like the Clean Water Act (CWA), Clean Air Act, Pollution Prevention Act (PPA) and Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, have changed how processing facilities handle products and dispose of waste. When a food facility discharges any waste into the environment, it must have a National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit as mandated in the CWA.

FAQs.question: What kind of assistance does the industry receive?
FAQs.answer: MODERATE assistance STEADY assistance

FAQs.question: What is the role of the National Pasta Association?
FAQs.answer: The Association liaises between pasta producers and Congress, advocating on behalf of such producers, as well as organizing events and seminars to update pasta producers on relevant industry information.

FAQs.question: How does AIB International assist bakers and food processors?
FAQs.answer: AIB International, a technology and information transfer center for bakers and food processors, assists bakers by providing a range of services, including regulatory assistance, sourcing ingredients and equipment, product evaluation, educational programs and warehouse inspection.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Pasta sales typically increase when the economy struggles, because pasta is an inexpensive meal.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: The price of wheat can fluctuate significantly and impact global demand.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in proximity to important suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Pasta makers in the Plains region have access to a steady supply of wheat and other agricultural inputs.

FAQs.question: How does your company invest in technology, such as 3D printing, to establish a competitive edge over your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Barilla hosts the Smart Pasta competition, which lets people submit designs for 3D printed pasta.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Automation has played a growing role in the pasta production process.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Health standards are crucial for any food production industry.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: There are both national and global pasta maker associations.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Average profit declines as companies invest in new types of pasta.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Errors in machinery can result in broken or poorly shaped pasta, so equipment must be frequently repaired and replaced.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to pass on cost increases to customers? What has been customers' response to the increases?
FAQs.answer: Given the volatility of commodity and energy prices, producers' ability to pass unexpected cost increases down the supply chain is vital to maintaining profitability.

FAQs.question: How hard is it to promote your company by word-of-mouth recommendations? How can you improve your company to receive better word-of-mouth recommendations?
FAQs.answer: Successful operators have reliable contracts with suppliers of key raw materials to reduce supply volatility. Guaranteed supplies at fixed prices minimize supply costs and aid production planning.

FAQs.question: Are you able to quickly and easily alter the services offered?
FAQs.answer: To achieve industry success, manufacturers must anticipate and respond to changes in consumer preferences in a timely manner.

FAQs.question: Do you track the level of disposable income? How do you mitigate the threat of declining disposable income?
FAQs.answer: An increase in disposable income bolsters consumer spending, including spending on premium items, such as organic and whole-grain products, that carry a higher price tag.

FAQs.question: How do fluctuating wheat prices affect your company?
FAQs.answer: When the price of wheat rises, typically this price is passed on to consumers through higher product prices. As the price of pasta increases, so does industry revenue.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of an appreciating dollar? How do you stimulate demand when the dollar depreciates?
FAQs.answer: The strength of the US dollar influences the competitiveness of domestically produced dry pasta items. A lower value of the US dollar, measured by the trade-weighted index, means the industry's products are more competitively priced globally.
